title: Can you identify these two typefaces?
content:
The monospaced one is used in James May's book 'How to land an A330 Airbus', and the grotesque one is from a 70's NASA technical report. Any pointers will be highly appreciated. Thanks.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Grotesque-NASAReport](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/typophile.com/files/Screen%20Shot%202013-03-04%20at%2001.05.22.png) | 18.02 KB |
| [Monospaced-JamesMayBook](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/typophile.com/files/Screen%20Shot%202013-03-04%20at%2001.14.44.png) | 396.73 KB |
author: johan80

comments.content:
The monospaced letters (but unfortunately not the numerals) are very similar to **[ProFontWindows](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/ProFontWindows)** free font designed by Andrew Welch (SQ Software, 1987)

The grotesque is very close to **[ITC Franklin Gothic Book](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=ITC&ffam=ITC%20Franklin%20Gothic%20Book%20-%20Regular&fid=f0fa0fd2fd18567fc887a33456871365&fsize=48&text=SIMPLIFIED%20CONTROL%20AND%20FLIGHT%20MANAGEMENT%20FOR%20THE%201980's&wrap=2)** with small differences in /G, /1 (you can use /I) and /8

The grotesque from 70's NASA technical report reminds me of letterings done with [Leroy Lettering Machine](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/typophile.com/node/79271) (including some suggestions for similars such as Leroy Lettering Light, Planscribe, Engineering Plot) Adding [Gordon](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/gordon/) and [Register Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/btn/register-sans-btn).  
Unfortunately, I don't have a match for the monospaced either but I can point point to a direction that you may find helpful: [NB55](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/neubauladen/nb55set) by [Neubauladen Stefan Gandl](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.neubauladen.com/), [NE Saber and Saber Hund](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.hypefortype.com/catalogsearch/result/?q=Neutura), suprb [ASCA and ASCA-D](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.youworkforthem.com/designer/48/suprb/), Identikal [Bennu Sans A and B](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.hypefortype.com/bennu-sans-a.html), [Gerusa](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/scannerlicker/gerusa/), [ARAME](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/dimitrelima/0arame/), [Roundabout](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/roundabout-nf)

Thanks for the prompt replies.

Leroy was a good pointer. I will pursue it further. Lineto's Gravur Condensed comes close as well.

Incidentally the monospace is also a Lineto creation called [Autoscape](http://web.archive.org/web/20131011232016/http:/lineto.com/1.0/cont_des_37.html). I had seen it in use in a degree project, and I managed to track down the guy, who then passed on the name to me. There is an obvious connection to ProFont like you mentioned.
